newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech cenbank says will aim to keep crown in band.
newsitem.headline: Czech cenbank says will aim to keep crown in band.

text.p: Czech National Bank Governor Josef Tosovsky on Friday said the central was committed to keeping the crown witin its current band.

"I said that we will try to keep the rate within the plus minus 7.5 percent band (against the mark/dollar cross rate). I dismissed speculation that we would want to move the crown in some way outside the band," Tosovsky told reporters after a meeting with business leaders.

Analysts recently have been debating whether a devaluation of the crown might be needed to boost exports and help stem a ballooning current account deficit. The gap is threatening to climb to close to six percent of GDP this year after about four percent last year.

The central bank fixes the crown daily within a band plus or minus 7.5 percent for the central parity of the mark/crown basket. The central bank has of late been fixing the crown roughly two percent above parity to match a modest net inflow of crown buying.

Tosovsky said a stronger crown "should help faster restructuring of our economy, to help increase the added-value faster...and to help to bring our country closer in productivity to the countries that we want to compare ourselves with", a clear reference to the European Union and especially Germany.
Tosovsky was speaking after a meeting on the Czech economy with Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus and top business executives at a government chateau east of Prague.
